Package number

Class BigNumber

java.lang.Object
number.BigNumber
public class BigNumber
extends java.lang.Object
Big Numbers implementation in base 10⁹ as part of ISMIN courses Handle basic operations such as sum, substract, product, modular sum, modular addition, modular multiplication Not very operational and benchmark are not very good :(
Version:
1.0
Author:
Eric

  • Field Summary

    Fields
    Modifier and Type Field Description
    static BigNumber MGY_N
    Constant BigNumber N for Montgomery Multiplication

    Constant BigNumber R for Montgomery Multiplication

    Constant BigNumber V for Montgomery Multiplication

    Return True if a is Odd Looks at the last array's case and convert the Integer stored into its Binary representation to check if the bit relative to 2⁰ is set or not.

    Return True is the Integer Array given is equals to zero, and False is not

    Modular Addition of this mod m Create a new Big Number whose value is equal to the modular sum of the two Big Numbers' value stored into the Array of 32 bits Integer
    int[] modularSub​(int[] x, int[] y, int[] mod)
    Do modular substract between two int Arrays given a int array value as Mod
    BigNumber modularSubstract​(BigNumber bigNumber, BigNumber m)
    Modular Substract of max(this,bigNumber) with min(this,bigNumber) mod m Create a new Big Number whose value is equal to the modular substract of the two Big Numbers' value stored into the Array of 32 bits Integer
    BigNumber montgomeryOperator​(BigNumber b, BigNumber N, BigNumber R, BigNumber V)
    Calculate this montgomeryOperator b = this.b.r^-1 mod N
    BigNumber mul​(BigNumber bigNumber)
    Product of this with bigNumber Create a new Big Number whose value is equal to the multiplication of the two Big Numbers' value stored into the Array of 32 bits Integer
    BigNumber mulMontgomery​(BigNumber bigNumber)
    Modular Multiplication of this with bigNumber mod MGY_N
    BigNumber multiMontgomery​(BigNumber b)
    Montgomery Multiplication of this with b Used for performance enhancement Algorithm : Let c = a.b mod N with a,b,N 1024 bits, and C its Montgomery representation Pick R = 10^k with 10^(k-1) <= N <= 10^k Let V = - N^(-1) mod R Let A and B be the Montgomery representations of a and b as this : A = a.R mod N = A montgomeryOperator R² mod N B = b.R mod N = B montgomeryOperator R² mod N C = A montgomeryOperator B Finally, c = a.b mod N = C montgomeryOperator 1 /!\ N,R,V and R² mod have a precalculated value !!
    int[] multiply​(int[] a, int[] b)
    Multiplication of two 32 bits Integer Array "Grade School" Algorithm
    BigNumber pow​(BigNumber k)
    (Not yet functional :( ) Return this^k Use the algorithm Square And Multiply combined with Montgomery's reduction
    java.lang.String removeZeros​(java.lang.String str)
    Remove right side zeros
    int[] rightShift​(int[] val, int k)
    Return val rightshifted by k
    BigNumber squareAndMultiply​(BigNumber k)
    ( Not functional yet :( ) Return this^k Note : this must have its Montgomery Representation This condition is not checked !
    java.lang.String stackToString​(int index)
    Return the string of the stack with the index i of this Add the leading zeros !
    int[] substract​(int[] big, int[] small)
    Substract of two Arrays of 32 bits Integer
    BigNumber substract​(BigNumber bigNumber)
    Substract of max(this,bigNumber) with min(this,bigNumber) Create a new Big Number whose value is equal to the substract of the two Big Numbers' value stored into the Array of 32 bits Integer
    int[] toBase2​(int[] val)  
    java.lang.String toString​(int[] res)
    Return a concatenate String of the value based on the Array of 32 bits Integer given in input
    int trueSize​(int[] a)
    Return non empty size of the Array Ex : {0,12} -> length = 2 but trueSize = 1
    int[] unitaryLeftShift​(int[] val)
    Return val left shifted by 1 Fragmented so that the long will not be overflowed !!

      m - - BigNumber modulo
      Returns:

      Parameters:
      bigNumber - - BigNumber to substract to this
      Returns:
      a BigNumber from this - bigNumber if this > bigNumber or from bigNumber - this

      public BigNumber mod10​(BigNumber mod)

      Parameters:

      Returns:

      public BigNumber div10​(BigNumber div)

      Parameters:

      Returns:
      a BigNumber from this / div

    • multiMontgomery

      public BigNumber multiMontgomery​(BigNumber b)
      Montgomery Multiplication of this with b Used for performance enhancement Algorithm : Let c = a.b mod N with a,b,N 1024 bits, and C its Montgomery representation Pick R = 10^k with 10^(k-1) <= N <= 10^k Let V = - N^(-1) mod R Let A and B be the Montgomery representations of a and b as this : A = a.R mod N = A montgomeryOperator R² mod N B = b.R mod N = B montgomeryOperator R² mod N C = A montgomeryOperator B Finally, c = a.b mod N = C montgomeryOperator 1 /!\ N,R,V and R² mod have a precalculated value !!
      Parameters:
      b - - BigNumber to do the modular multiplication with
      Returns:
      a BigNumber equals to this * b mod MGY_N

    • montgomeryOperator

      public BigNumber montgomeryOperator​(BigNumber b, BigNumber N, BigNumber R, BigNumber V)
      Calculate this montgomeryOperator b = this.b.r^-1 mod N
      Parameters:
      b - - BigNumber
      N - - Constant BigNumber precalculated
      R - - Constant BigNumber precalculated
      V - - Constant BigNumber precalculated
      Returns:
      a BigNumber equals to this * b * R^-1 mod N

      Returns:
      a BigNumber this^k

      Parameters:

      Returns:
      a BigNumber equals to this^k

    • binGCD

      public int[] binGCD​(int[] u, int[] v)
      (Some bugs to fix.... :'( ) Calculate GCD of a and b Algorithm B from "Art of Computer Programming Knuth vol.2" section 4.5.2 B1. [Find Power of 2] Set k <- 0, and then repeatedly set k <- k+1, u <- u/2, v <- v/2 zero or more times until u and v are not both even. B2. [Initialize] Now the original values of u and v have been divided by 2^k and at least one of their present value is odd. If u is odd, set t <- -v and go to B4. Otherwise set t <- u B3. [Halve t] At this point, t is even and nonzero. Set t <- t/2 B4. [Is t even ?] If t is even, go back to B3 B5. [Reset max(u,v)]. If t>0, set u <- t; otherwise set v <- -t B6. [Substract] Set t <- u - v. If t!=0, go back to B3. Otherwise the algorithm terminates with u*2^k as the output.
      Parameters:
      u - - int array
      v - - int array
      Returns:
      a int array equals to gcd(u,v)

    • gcd

      public int gcd​(long a, long b)
      Calculate GCD of Long a and b
      Parameters:
      a - - Long
      b - - Long
      Returns:

      public int[] unitaryLeftShift​(int[] val)

      Parameters:

      Returns:
      a int array equals to val<<1
